div.p: An element in WRITING PRODUCTION . PANTHOLOGIZATION should enclose a sentence or more, including a title or an editor’s name. It has no mandatory or optional attributes or sub-elements, but you may want to include with the anthology title a press (captured in ORGNAME), dates, and other significant writers' names. This element creates a record of a work's selection for and appearance in anthologies; it contains relevant details surrounding significant instances when a text is anthologized (how it's framed; how it's described; how frequently it is chosen). Used (not exclusively) for inclusion in important modern or contemporary collections (e.g. Gilbert and Gubar, Palgrave, Norton), or for first or significant appearance in historical ones.

div.codeblock: <PANTHOLOGIZATION>Anne Askew's writing was excerpted in Thomas Bentley's Monument of Matrones, 1582.</PANTHOLOGIZATION>

div.p: Discussion is also warranted when anthology editors have presented a narrow or selective notion of a writer’s oeuvre. <PANTHOLOGIZATION>Emily Brontë is presented as a poet longing for death in a 1951 anthology.</PANTHOLOGIZATION>
Question: My author edited anthologies; do I include that here?
Answer: No. If the author herself edited an anthology, record that in genre with a genreName attribute for anthology.
